abstracts.cdata!:
The project ratings are as follows:
            Project outcome is unsatisfactory, sustainability is likely,
            institutional development impact is modest, Bank performance
            is satisfactory, and Borrower performance is satisfactory.
            Lessons learned include the following:1) Risks common to all
            the Financial Intermediary Loans (FILs) are amplified when
            the FIL is implemented in a post-conflict environment.
            Lenders face massive information deficiencies that cannot be
            properly filled because of the lack of transparency in the
            enterprise sector, and the embryonic development of the
            financial infrastructure and financial products, which are
            necessary to support prudent lending activity. In addition,
            lenders cannot rely upon courts enabling the enforcement of
            creditors rights and contracts within a reasonable period of
            time, and at a reasonable cost. 2) In post-conflict
            situations, project performance indicators for emergency
            FILs should be designed to measure the impact of the
            emergency financing in restarting economic activity rather
            than the volume of loan disbursement. The lack of
            appropriate performance indicators causes problems during
            supervision because it prevents a proper monitoring and
            evaluation of achievement of project development objectives.
            3) Effective risk mitigation measures are generally not
            available in the emergency of a post-conflict situation.
            They become available during project implementation to the
            extent that the authorities are strongly committed in
            reforming the economy, and have well-prioritized and
            successfully implemented their reform plans. 4) The
            implementation of a line of credit in a post-conflict
            situation requires intensive supervision and a strong
            ability and willingness to adjust the project's
            sub-lending arrangements to the rapid developments of the
            banking sector, and to the changing capacity of the banking
            sector to absorb credit risks. 5) The existence of
            non-market based, fully-subsidized grant programs with
            similar development objectives negatively affects the
            repayment records of credit programs on market-based terms.
            6) In a post-conflict situation characterized by the absence
            of a financial intermediary willing and capable of lending
            to small and medium enterprises (SMEs), the establishment of
            an ad-hoc non-bank financial institution and the outsourcing
            of its management to an experienced consulting company can
            serve as effective measures to address the need for the
            timely provision of much needed financing to eligible SMEs.
            7) The establishment of an ad-hoc financial institution for
            implementation of an emergency line of credit simultaneously
            creates the challenge of identifying and implementing,
            within the typically short implementation period of an
            emergency loan, an exit strategy that does not result in
            distortionary effects in the credit market or contingent
            liabilities for the government's budget (e.g., a
            state-owned development bank). Factors to help achieve a
            successful exit strategy include: (1) careful and close
            monitoring of the rapid changes of the intermediation
            capacity of the banking sector; (2) a banking sector's
            well-recognized market positioning of the project
            implementing financial institution as an interim credit
            intermediation mechanism that not only is not in competition
            with the banking sector, but it also mobilizes technical
            assistance to further strengthen its institutional capacity;
            and (3) a good policy dialogue with authorities fully
            committed in implementing reform plans.
